summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 2020 between FBI forensic examiners and U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel regarding the transfer and processing of digital evidence from the Epstein investigation. It details logistical challenges, data volume (~350 GB export), and the need to provide searchable materials from devices seized in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands. This document is a chain of emails from February to May 2020 between the FBI's New York CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team) and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY). The correspondence concerns the coordination, processing, and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, as well as from his person upon arrest. The emails highlight significant logistical challenges, data management issues, and delays in the investigation.

persons.name: M, I. (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator, Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: FBI forensic examiner coordinating the extraction and transfer of digital evidence from seized devices in the Epstein case to the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: M, (USANYS) [Contractor]
persons.context: Contractor for the U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) receiving and processing the digital evidence, asking logistical questions about the data transfer.

persons.name: Ted
persons.context: Mentioned as a potential participant in a conference call to discuss the evidence processing and transfer issues.

connections.description: FBI forensic examiner and USAO contractor coordinating the technical transfer and processing of seized digital evidence for the Epstein case.
Both are involved in the legal and investigative process regarding the Epstein evidence, with M from the FBI's forensic team and Ted from the U.S. Attorney's Office.

events.title: Hard Drive Transfer Coordination
events.description: Contractor confirms receipt of a hard drive containing Epstein case evidence and requests a call to discuss its contents.

events.title: Evidence Export Initiation
events.description: FBI examiner informs contractor that the hard drive containing evidence is beginning its journey to them, referencing a large volume of data.

events.title: Evidence Inventory Provided
events.description: FBI examiner sends an updated listing of all evidence gathered in New York, including device types and data sizes, with a promise to provide USVI materials later.

events.title: Search of Epstein's residences
events.description: Search warrants were executed at Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, resulting in the seizure of numerous electronic devices and media.

events.title: Search of Epstein's residences
events.description: Search warrants were executed at Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, resulting in the seizure of numerous electronic devices and media.

events.title: Email update on evidence processing
events.description: FBI examiner M informs the U.S. Attorney's Office that due to reduced staffing (one day a week), there are significant delays. They promise to provide a list of seized devices by the following Thursday.

events.title: Scheduling of conference call
events.description: The parties coordinate to schedule a conference call for April 8, 2020, to discuss the issues with the Epstein search warrant evidence processing and transfer.

events.title: Prior property search
events.description: Reference to a July 2007 search of one of Epstein's properties, from which 9 IDE hard drives (3 copies of 3 drives) were found in his Manhattan apartment during the 2020 search.

locations: One Saint Andrews (address referenced for data delivery)
New York mansion (Epstein's New York residence)
Southern District of New York (U.S. Attorney's Office jurisdiction)
California (where the case team was traveling)
keyFacts: The FBI was preparing a massive data export (~350 GB) of digital evidence from devices seized in both New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands as part of the Epstein investigation.

There were significant challenges in providing the evidence in a searchable format usable by the U.S. Attorney's Office, requiring a re-export of raw data from devices including Macs, Windows computers, iPhones, iPads, and loose media.

The correspondence reveals tension over methodology, with the FBI noting the USAO's insistence on using the Relativity e-discovery tool added months of work and was incapable of viewing all forensic data.
Logistical issues, including FBI staffing levels and the COVID-19 pandemic (teleworking), impacted the timeline for evidence transfer.
The evidence included over 500,000 emails on one particular item and data from devices with APFS file systems (common on newer Macs) which were difficult to process.
Significant digital evidence was seized from Epstein's New York and U.S. Virgin Islands residences, including computers, hard drives, thumb drives, CDs, and servers.
The FBI's forensic team faced major challenges in processing and organizing the data, including network issues and the sheer volume (over 1 million documents).
The U.S. Attorney's Office reported critical problems with the received data, such as an inability to link emails with attachments and mismatched control numbers, hindering review.
Evidence from a prior 2007 search of an Epstein property was found among the items seized in 2020.
The investigation was experiencing operational delays in early 2020, partly due to reduced FBI staffing and the COVID-19 pandemic's impact.
